query: What did Barry Hughes think about reasonable punishment?
summary: Barry Hughes believed that the law should reflect contemporary society and the law is evolutionary in nature, and should be evolved in nature. And just as if we go back 50 years there were types of behaviour that we might all have contemplated back then as being socially acceptable, many of those types of behaviours were not now, so the law had changed to reflect the fact that that was simply not acceptable.

query: Summarize the discussion about the divergence between the law in England and Wales.
summary: According to Barry Hughes, there was a spectrum of offending within the United Kingdom. The first stage was whether there was sufficient evidence to provide a realistic prospect of conviction. If there wasn't enough evidence, the police would take a view that the evidential test may have been satisfied because the defence had been removed, but it wouldn't be in the public interest to prosecute. In the second stage, the CPS would decide whether it was an offence that was so serious that it should be brought before a criminal court.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the divergence of criminal law?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that it could be dealt with within the existing guidance, so he did not see a need to update or amend the guidance. On the evidential stage, he doubted that they would need to do much, other than to make people aware that the defence was not available in Wales in the same way that it was in England, and they might have some light-touch guidance around that. When it comes to the public interest stage, that's a little more specialist and they would have to develop more with respect to that.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the need for the CPS in England to be aware of the changes?

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the criminal law in Wales and England diverging in this particular instance?

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the risk of malicious reporting against parents involved in private family law cases?

query: Summarize the discussion about universal adoption.

Kay Martin answered that it was absolutely not used as a recruitment tool, because most of them, as you see, valued the Welsh bac in many cases. So, they wouldn't deliberately tell people, "Come in and you won't have to do it."

query: Summarize the discussion about the baccalaureate.
summary: According to Dafydd Evans, it was not a case of squeezing things out. It was part of what the college's curriculum offered—there was no doubt about that—and then people make a choice according to what they need to do to actually progress to what their future. There was a big range, and some really high achievers coming into the sector as well. So, the Welsh bac starts to do some of those things at different levels.

query: What did Nick Brazil think about the perception that parents had about the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: According to Nick Brazil, the perception of parents was steering the way rather than the actual benefits for the pupil in the institution. Education was about offering the range and offering it correctly. So, what parents and learners were looking for was for the range of options.

query: What did Dafydd Evans think about introducing a specialist teacher-training qualification to deliver the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: He thought that introducing specialist teacher training qualification would actually help in some way in improving its status and perception and so on. However, it would make it into quite an intensive selling process for colleges when they had got to overcome that negative perception. As people have said already, it was possible to talk parents and learners round, but then that's time spent having to do that selling job when they should be talking about other things.

query: Summarize the discussion about universal adoption.
summary: Kay Martin thought that the Welsh baccalaureate should go back to the original vision, which all of us would buy into 100 per cent. Therefore, they needed to raise the profile amongst parents in particular. They needed to spend less time in checking what they've done on assessment and more time in the doing, and the experiential learning that they need to do, rather than it being too much of a paper exercise. They also needed to incorporate mentorship programmes, they send people out, and they just need to incorporate that better.

query: What did Kirsty Williams AM think about the changes to the curriculum?
summary: Kirsty Williams explained that there had been broad support for the curriculum changes that they were proposing. There was a concerted effort and a plan drawn up to try and ensure that there was as much engagement, knowledge and opportunity for the broad principles of what they were doing. There were 24 focus groups that were arranged for children and young people. In October, there would be a number of workshops lasting three days at a time where those practitioners would continue that process of feedback with our curriculum and assessment group and all those people involved. By November, they would expect the QI groups to have completed their work and would want them to be in a position to hand over the refinements to an editorial process, and that had to be done in both languages.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think about the religious education and relationships and sexuality education?
summary: Kirsty Williams thought that they had demonstrated that they were listening to people, that there had been concern expressed about certainty and having a national approach on some of these issues, and they had taken steps to address that and they would continue to reflect with their partners who were co-constructing this with us.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think about potential unintended consequences of the curriculum?
summary: Kirsty Williams thought that the curriculum was a core element of the national mission for education in Wales and they would not proceed with anything that they thought could lead to an exacerbation of an achievement gap. Therefore, they needed more research into Welsh education, not less.

query: What did Kirsty Williams AM think about segregation within schools between different groups of pupils?
summary: Kirsty Williams said that there was no evidence that the curriculum could exacerbate segregation. However, she did believe that the flexibility that they were allowing people would lead to a curriculum and more meaningful lessons for some children in schools who were in danger of disengaging because they did not understand why they were being asked to learn what they were learning, they didn't see the relevance of what they're learning to what they may want to do or how their lives were, or they didn’t see themselves reflected. So, the curriculum on its own could play a part, but it would only be as good as the four enabling elements that surround it. In the end, no education system, whatever its curriculum, can exceed the quality of the people who stand in front of our children day in, day out.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think about the lessons learned from Scotland?
summary: Kirsty Williams thought that they had learned a lot about how they quality control the content, even though the content would be completely different in Wales. They had pioneers who worked with clusters to test the development of that concept before they were looking for schools to go away and develop a larger amount of content. And they had embraced experts who were involved in that process who were part of their curriculum assessment group.

query: What did Kirsty Williams AM think about the professional development preparation?
summary: Kirsty Williams said that it was the largest investment in professional learning since the history of devolution. The four regional consortia were working together to provide consistency for classroom teachers and teaching assistants, and then the next stage of that development was for subject specifics. They were also working with the regions to revisit and improve their coaching and mentoring schemes that they had across the system. And they were looking at developing potentially a stronger set of support, again on a national basis, for those who were newly qualified, beginning their teaching career, because they just simply didn't have a structure that allowed them to do that.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think about the issue of teachers who were not trained in Wales?
summary: Kirsty Williams thought it was not an insurmountable issue. The structure they had in place across the regions was working with schools on their readiness to actually—not readiness to engage—start to deliver as they move through to the future. At a regional level, they require the regions to engage with all schools through the cluster model.

query: What did Kirsty Williams AM think about the accountability?
summary: According to Kirsty, there was a clear distinction between assessment for learning and an accountability in the system. The primary purpose for assessment was for that professional to be able to know how to move that child's educational journey on, and the purpose for categorisation was not to make a judgment on a school in the sense of a league table; it was a triage process, categorisation.

query: What did Kirsty Williams AM think about the public assurance at those early steps of the teaching standards and the leadership standards?
summary: According to Kirsty, the first level of accountability in that system had to be the professionalism of an individual member of staff. That's where it started, and it ended in Estyn. Then the schools' ability—whether they do that well or whether they don't do it well—will be judged by Estyn.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think about the Welsh dimension in the new curriculum?
summary: Kirsty Williams thought it was really important that whatever resources they had to support Welsh dimension were really broad and not confined to specific areas. They had to contextualise that learning continuum depending on the setting where a child was being taught.

query: What did Kirsty Williams AM think about physical activity under the new curriculum for Wales?
summary: Janet Finch-Saunders AM wanted to know whether all children and young people, where appropriate, would be given the opportunity to undertake physical activity, because if they were not then that school would be in breach of the expectations that would be set out in statute. Kirsty said that all children will be given that opportunity.

query: What did Kirsty Williams AM think about the transition to post-16 education?
summary: According to Kirsty, one of the themes of the feedback from further education had been the need to ensure that the transition between the systems don't just clash against each other. So, what they intend to do for EOTAS and PRU is to set a minimum standard around the purposes, around the cross-cutting themes and health and well-being, and then there will be an expectation that in conjunction with the child and the family an appropriate addition would be put in place to meet the needs of that child, recognising that they could have very different needs.
